description: June 4- Turkey is free to choose whether or not to put the S-400 air defense missile systems supplied from Russia on combat duty, Russian Ambassador in Ankara Alexei Yerkhov said.  "Turkey made a sovereign decision to buy this kind of weapon from the Russian Federation," he said. June 3- Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin and his South Korean counterpart Chung...
text:
Corridors of Power

Ankara makes its own decisions on using S-400 - Russian ambassador

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - Turkey is free to choose whether or not to put the
S-400 air defense missile systems supplied from Russia on combat duty, Russian
Ambassador in Ankara Alexei Yerkhov said.

"The decision whether or not to put a particular weapon system on combat duty
is the sovereign decision of the weapon's owner," the embassy quoted Yerkhov
as saying in a statement published on its website.

"Turkey made a sovereign decision to buy this kind of weapon from the Russian
Federation," he said.

"Good, we respect their decision. We sold Turkey what it wanted to buy from
us. Now these systems are owned by Turkey. And it will make the relevant
decision," Yerkhov said.

Corridors of Power

Russian, S. Korean PMs discuss prospects for economic projects involving N.
Korea

MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin and his
South Korean counterpart Chung Sye-kyun have discussed in a telephone call the
prospects for implementing trilateral projects involving Russia, South Korea,
and North Korea, the Russian government's press service said.

During the phone conversation, the prime ministers expressed "their mutual
interest in intensifying trade, economic, scientific, and technological
cooperation, as well as cooperation in the fields of energy and transport
infrastructure," the press service said.

They also discussed the schedule of upcoming contacts between the two
countries' governments, it said.

Corridors of Power

Russia ships new batch of MiG-29 fighter jets to Syria - Russian embassy

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - Russia has shipped a new batch of MiG-29 fighter
aircraft to Syria, the Russian embassy to Syria said.

"Syrian Arab Army received the second batch of advanced MiG-29 fighter jets
from Russia," the embassy said on Twitter.

The planes have been shipped as part of military and technical cooperation
between the two countries, and Syrian pilots have already started flying the
planes, it said.

The Syrian state news agency SANA reported citing a source on May 30 that the
Syrian army received a unit of Russian MiG-29s. The handover ceremony took
place at the Russian airbase Hmeimim in Syria, it said.

Corridors of Power

Ankara makes its own decisions on using S-400 - Russian ambassador

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - Turkey is free to choose whether or not to put the
S-400 air defense missile systems supplied from Russia on combat duty, Russian
Ambassador in Ankara Alexei Yerkhov said.

"The decision whether or not to put a particular weapon system on combat duty
is the sovereign decision of the weapon's owner," the embassy quoted Yerkhov
as saying in a statement published on its website.

"Turkey made a sovereign decision to buy this kind of weapon from the Russian
Federation," he said.

"Good, we respect their decision. We sold Turkey what it wanted to buy from
us. Now these systems are owned by Turkey. And it will make the relevant
decision," Yerkhov said.

The diplomat compared Turkey's decision to activate the S-400 systems with the
decision to start using a purchased vehicle.

"Say I'm a car dealer. You come to me and say you want to buy a car. Alright.
We conclude an agreement, you pay the money, and I give you the car and the
keys. The car is yours. You can drive it to the beach or use it to transport
potatoes. If you want, you can install a machinegun on the roof and fight a
war. You can also park your car in the garage. That's your decision," Yerkhov
said.

Corridors of Power

Two FSMTC, Trade Ministry employees suspected of corruption - source

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - A deputy division head at Russia's Federal Service
for Military-Technical Cooperation (FSMTC), a head of department at the
Ministry of Industry and Trade and the CEO of Nizhegorodskoye Aviatsionnoye
Obshchestvo LLC (NAO, or Nizhny Novgorod Aviation Society) have been detained
on suspicion of a two-million-ruble bribe, an informed source told Interfax.

"Chief executive officer of NAO LLC Vasily Klepalov, deputy head of a division
at FSMTC Sergei Garmash and a head of department at the Ministry of Industry
and Trade Rizvan Gayrbekov were detained yesterday in a criminal case as
people suspected of giving and accepting a bribe (Articles 290 and 291 of the
Russian Criminal Code)," the source said.

According to the source, in late May, Klepalov, acting through intermediaries,
including Garmash, gave Gayrbekov 2,000,000 rubles in return for a license
permitting his business to pursue certain types of economic activity.

Spokesperson for the Moscow department of the Russian Investigative Committee
Yulia Ivanova told Interfax that the committee is investigating a criminal
case against some people suspected of 'accepting a bribe in an especially
large amount,' 'giving a bribe' and 'mediation in bribery', including an
employee of the Russian Ministry of Industry and Trade and three others
suspected of bribery facilitation.

Ivanova did not provide any further detail, including the names of the
suspects, remarking that the Ministry of Industry and Trade is cooperating
with investigators.

"Today, the investigation asked the court to select a measure of restraint on
suspects [in the case]," she said.

Aviation

Mi-38 helicopter makes emergency landing in Moscow region due to engine
problem

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - A Mil Mi-38 multirole helicopter has made an
emergency landing in the Moscow region due to excessive engine vibration
during a test flight, the Russian Helicopters Holding said in a statement.

"Excessive vibration in one of the engines of the Mil Mi-38 helicopter
prototype operated by the Mil and Kamov National Helicopter Center [the design
bureau of Russian Helicopters] was registered in the course of a scheduled
test flight on June 3, when the emergency mode of engine operation was being
tested," a holding representative said.

The engine problem occurred during the fourth attempt to run the engine in
emergency mode, while the previous three attempts were successful, he said.

"The crew decided to perform an approach and successfully performed the
landing. No one was hurt in the incident, and no damage was done to the
helicopter," the representative said.

A commission is being formed to establish the cause of the incident once the
information from the objective control equipment is decoded and analyzed.

Aviation

Sharipov of Rostec's KRET becomes new head of Tupolev - UAC

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - Tupolev Company, which designs and manufactures
strategic bombers, has been headed up by Ronis Sharipov of Rostec's radio
electronic holding company KRET, the United Aircraft Corporation (UAC) told
Interfax.

"In accordance with the decisions by the UAC board of directors and the
Tupolev [part of Rostec] board of directors, Ronis Sharipov has been appointed
Tupolev's general director starting June 5, 2020," the UAC press service said.

He is replacing Alexander Konyukhov, who is leaving the company, the press
service said.

"Under Konyukhov, Tupolev rolled out a large-scale program to reequip the
Kazan aviation plant, launched projects to upgrade the strategic bomber line,
effected the first flight of the profoundly upgraded [Tupolev] Tu-160, and
laid the foundations for the subsequent sustainable development of its design
bureau and enterprise," it said.

Sharipov's experience will "enable further implementation of strategic
development plans and the important state tasks facing the enterprise and the
design bureau," the press service said.

Sharipov has led the Kazan-based Scientific Production Association named after
Shimko (part of KRET) since 2013.

Tupolev comprises the Moscow-based design bureau and the Kazan-based aviation
plant named after Gorbunov. The company designs and manufactures the entire
line of strategic and long-range aircraft: deeply upgraded missile-carrying
bombers Tu-160M, Tu-95MSM, and Tu-22M3M and the next-generation PAK DA
strategic bomber.

Konyukhov has led the company since 2016. On June 30, he was appointed
Tupolev's general director while retaining his post as UAC Vice President for
Strategic and Special Aviation.

Space and Rocket Building

Soyuz MS-17 crew approved for ISS mission this fall

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - The crew of the Soyuz MS-17 spaceship that will
head to the International Space Station (ISS) in October will include Russian
cosmonauts Sergei Ryzhikov and Sergei Kud-Sverchkov, as well as NASA astronaut
Kathleen Rubins, Roscosmos said.

"By resolution of the inter-agency commission, the main crew of Expedition 64
will consist of Roscosmos cosmonauts Sergei Ryzhikov (expedition 64 commander;
Soyuz MS commander) and Sergei Kud-Sverchkov (Expedition 64 flight engineer;
Soyuz MS flight engineer), as well as NASA astronaut Kathleen Rubins
(Expedition 64 flight engineer; Soyuz MS flight engineer 2)," Roscosmos said.

The members of the backup crew are Russians Oleg Novitsky and Pyotr Dubrov and
NASA's Mark Vande Hei. Also, in light of the Covid-19 pandemic, another
reserve crew has been formed, which is made up of Anton Shkaplerov and Andrei
Babkin.

It was reported earlier this month that Novitsky, Dubrov, Kud-Sverchkov, and
Ryzhikov had arrived in the United States to train for the ISS flight.

The Soyuz MS-17 was scheduled to launch in October 2020. Roscosmos executive
director for manned missions Sergei Krikalyov said that for the first time in
20 years, the crew was to be made up of only Russians. However, later, because
the U.S. manned spaceships were not ready, NASA asked Roscosmos for additional
seats on Soyuz spaceships.

Initially, the main crew of the Soyuz MS-17 was to include Anatoly Ivanishin
and Ivan Vagner, but they were sent to the ISS on board Soyuz MS-16, instead
of the main crew's Andrei Babkin and Nikolai Tikhonov, who were barred from
the flight for medical reasons.

Space and Rocket Building

Coronavirus prompts Roscosmos to set up 3rd crew in addition to main, backup
crews for flight to ISS set for Oct

MOSCOW. May 29 (Interfax) - The coronavirus epidemic has prompted Roscosmos to
set up a reserve crew, in addition to the main and a backup crews, for the
Soyuz MS-17 spacecraft due to fly to the International Space Station (ISS) in
October, Roscosmos said on Friday.

"The reserve crew, which has been formed amid the ongoing coronavirus
pandemic, will include Roscosmos Cosmonauts Anton Shkaplerov (commander of the
Soyuz-MS manned spacecraft and a flight engineer of ISS Expedition 64) and
Andrei Babkin (a flight engineer of the Soyuz-MS manned spacecraft and a
flight engineer of ISS Expedition 64)," Roscosmos said.

Space and Rocket Building

Roscosmos to send experts to Kourou to check for possible leakage of oxidizer
from Fregat booster

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The alarm of an oxidizer vapor detection system
has gone off in the place where the Russian-made Fregat booster is being
stored at the Kourou Space Centre in French Guiana, the press service for the
Russian state corporation Roscosmos told Interfax on Friday.

"On May 21, 2020, the French side reported that a periodical alarm actuation
in the oxidizer vapor detection system took place in the place where the
Fregat booster is stored at the Kourou spaceport in French Guiana," the
Roscosmos press service said.

"To evaluate the situation and facilitate appropriate measures, the managers
of NPO Lavochkin, Glavcosmos, and TsENKI are taking all measures to organize
the departure of a group of experts to French Guiana," Roscosmos said.

"The group's arrival at the Guiana Space Centre is expected in the first ten
days of June 2020. All the works will be carried out in compliance with
sanitary-epidemiological requirements," Roscosmos said.

"The Fregat booster is being stored inside a premise meeting all international
safety standards, including environmental, and poses no threat to the
servicing personnel or the environment," it said.

The Kourou spaceport, from which various rockets, including Russian-made
Soyuz-ST in the interests of foreign commercial customers are, launched, has
suspended operations since March amid the coronavirus pandemic.

After Kourou suspended operations, Roscosmos evacuated almost 300 employees to
Russia on board several flights. Nine NPO Lavochkin experts supposed to
complete critical by-the-book procedures with the Fregat-MT booster at the
Guiana Space Centre were the last to leave French Guiana in late April. They
finished necessary works and departed from a Cayenne airport on April 24.

Space and Rocket Building

Roscosmos on Crew Dragon's launch: It is very important to have two options of
traveling to ISS

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Russian state space corporation Roscosmos has
welcomed Saturday's successful launch of the manned aircraft Crew Dragon in
the U.S. and noted the importance of a co-existence of two transport systems
that can deliver crews to the International Space Station.

"It is very important to have at least two opportunities to get to the
station. Since you never know... Things have happened in space, and there
should be at least two transport systems capable of ensuring the presence of
crews from different countries on board the ISS," Roscosmos spokesman Vladimir
Ustimenko wrote on Twitter.

Commenting on the successful launch of Crew Dragon, Ustimenko said, "What has
happened should have happened a long time ago. Now not only the Russians but
also the Americans will fly to the ISS. That's great!"

As reported earlier, a SpaceX capsule carrying two NASA astronauts docked at
the ISS at 5:16 p.m. Moscow time on Sunday.

Crew Dragon, on board of which two NASA astronauts, Robert Behnken and Douglas
Hurley, departed from Cape Canaveral in Florida on Saturday afternoon to reach
the ISS in about 19 hours, is the first manned aircraft launched form the U.S.
since 2011, when the final space shuttle mission was completed.

The two U.S. astronauts lifted off in SpaceX's Crew Dragon spacecraft on a
Falcon 9 rocket from Launch Complex 39A in Florida at 3:22 p.m. EDT on May 30.
Initially, the launch was due earlier on May 27 but ended up being delayed 15
minutes to blast-off due to bad weather.

The launch was performed under the contract between NASA and SpaceX on
creating an aircraft and a launch vehicle for commercial manned missions to
the ISS.

This Crew Dragon mission is the spaceship's last big trial before a NASA
certification for regular commercial manned missions to the ISS. In March
2019, a similar pilotless spacecraft completed the first successful
experimental spaceflight to the station.

Since 2011, U.S. astronauts had been using Russia's Soyuz spacecraft to reach
the ISS. NASA pays Russia for seats on board a Soyuz spacecraft. In
particular, This May, NASA agreed to pay Roscosmos $90.2 million for one seat
on board the Soyuz, which is due to depart for the ISS on October.

Roscosmos head Dmitry Rogozin said on May 25 that Russia was following with
interest preparations for the launch of the manned spacecraft Crew Dragon to
the ISS. The return of Americans to this work will help increase the number of
Russian cosmonauts on board the station, he said.

"It is with great interest that we're watching the preparations for this
launch. We have several motives for this. Indeed, for the past nine years,
since summer 2011, only Russia, only Roscosmos, has facilitated the delivery
of all international crews to the ISS: Americans, Europeans, the Japanese, and
Canadians," Rogozin said on the Komsomolskaya Pravda radio station.

"Yes, we have, of course, made some money on that, but in fact, the
responsibility associated with supporting this transport system, the continual
delivery to the ISS, has been colossal; it's not worth the money: the cost is
nerves, the health of the people in charge of manned space," Rogozin said.

"We would be very happy if the Americans came up with an alternative manned
transport system. It's a natural process, such a great power as the U.S., I
imagine what they went through all these nine years, not being able to deliver
astronauts to the ISS on their spacecraft [...] Let's wish them professional
success," he said.

Russia is also interested in the technical side of the project, Rogozin said.

Unburdening Russian spacecraft will help increase the number of cosmonauts on
the station, he said. "We've reduced our crews to two cosmonauts, who are in
orbit continually. Sometimes there was only one, the captain, in orbit. This
is wrong. This hinders the entire scientific program which we associate with
the ISS," Rogozin said.

Space and Rocket Building

Rogozin congratulates NASA, SpaceX on Crew Dragon's successful space journey,
hopes for further cooperation

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Russia is hoping for further space cooperation
with the United States, Roscosmos head Dmitry Rogozin said.

"Dear Jim Bridenstine, it's safe to congratulate you at this point with a
successful launch and docking. Bravo! I know how anxious you were for this
major event to become a success. I wish NASA team to successfully finish up
reconstructing its national space transportation system," Rogozin wrote on
Twitter.

"Please convey my sincere greetings to Elon Musk (I loved his joke) and SpaceX
team. Looking forward to further cooperation!" the Roscosmos head wrote in
English.

The launch of the Crew Dragon spacecraft atop a Falcon 9 rocket was carried
out from Launch Complex 39A at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida on
Saturday.

The Crew Dragon, which delivered NASA astronauts Douglas Hurley and Robert
Behnken into orbit for an experimental spaceflight to the International Space
Station (ISS), became the first U.S. manned spacecraft, which has been
launched from the territory of the U.S. since 2011, when the country
terminated its space shuttle program. The U.S. spacecraft docked to the ISS on
Sunday afternoon.

Space and Rocket Building

Roscosmos announces testing of 2 new rockets later this year

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Roscosmos will test two new rockets later this
year and resume its lunar program in 2021, spokesman Vladimir Ustimenko said.

"We'll test two new rockets later this year, and resume our lunar program next
year. It will be exciting!" Ustimenko tweeted.

Ustimenko did not, however, say what particular rockets he meant.

On May 27, Roscosmos head Dmitry Rogozin said that the second test launch of
the Angara heavy-lift rocket might take place this fall and preparations for
the new strategic missile Sarmat's flight tests were up and running.

"This year we will give the heavy-lift Angara [rocket] to the test site for
launching, for flight tests. We are resuming the tests of this heavy rocket,
which was almost fine-tuned. I think that we will carry out flight tests of
this rocket this fall," Rogozin said on the Soloviev Live channel on YouTube.

Tests of the Angara rocket are expected to be completed by 2022, Rogozin said.
"We are switching to serial production in 2023," he said.

Speaking about the work on the new Russian-made strategic missile Sarmat,
Rogozin said that preparations for its flight trials were proceeding as
planned.

"We are systematically and consistently carrying out the tests of a new
strategic combat missile system. I hope that we will begin its flight tests as
scheduled by the president. I refer to the Sarmat system. We are manufacturing
it," Rogozin said.

Space and Rocket Building

Roscosmos and NASA holding talks on mutual provision of seats aboard
spacecraft bound for ISS

NUR-SULTAN. June 2 (Interfax) - Roscosmos and NASA are holding negotiations on
providing seats for Russian cosmonauts and U.S. astronauts on each other's
spacecraft to fly to the International Space Station (ISS), the Russian state
space corporation's representative in Kazakhstan Anatoly Krasnikov said.

"We in the Roscosmos State Corporation are sincerely happy for our American
colleagues, that their test mission of the Dragon spacecraft and its docking
[with the ISS] went as planned and that everything worked out for them. We
whole-heartedly congratulate them. This is a truly enormous success for them.
This is great. The Roscosmos State Corporation and NASA are currently holding
negotiations on mutual provision of seats for flights to the ISS," Krasnikov
said at a press briefing on Tuesday.

"In other words, this is a situation where Russian cosmonauts will fly aboard
American spacecraft, and American astronauts will continue flying on board our
spacecraft," he said.

"Clearly, this is an urgent necessity, because all of us see now that a new
transportation system has emerged to take humans to orbit, to the ISS, and of
course people who fly there should know how to operate both one transportation
system and the other transportation system," he said.

NASA and SpaceX successfully launched the Demo-2 mission last Saturday,
sending the Crew Dragon spacecraft built by Elon Musk's SpaceX company into
space. The astronauts docked with the ISS and entered the station on May 31.

Crew Dragon, carrying NASA astronauts Douglas Hurley and Robert Behnken,
became the first U.S.-crewed spacecraft to lift off from U.S. soil since 2011,
when the Space Shuttle Program was retired.

The SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Crew Dragon spacecraft blasted off
from the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral on May 30. The launch was
initially expected to take place on May 27, but was postponed 15 minutes
before takeoff due to adverse weather.

The launch was carried out under the contract between NASA and SpaceX to build
a spacecraft and a launch vehicle for commercial flights of astronauts to the
ISS.

Space and Rocket Building

Baikonur Cosmodrome won't stand idle after Crew Dragon launch - Roscosmos rep

NUR-SULTAN. June 2 (Interfax) - The Baikonur Cosmodrome, which Russia leases
from Kazakhstan, will not stand idle following the May 30 launch of the U.S.
crewed spacecraft Crew Dragon, representative of the Roscosmos Russian State
Space Corporation in Kazakhstan Anatoly Krasnikov said.

"It's a big plus for us that such a transportation system has appeared. It's a
big plus for us that the American side is interested in joint work. As regards
the prospects of the Baikonur Cosmodrome, naturally, I'd like to say that we
understand that the infrastructure for crewed space missions and for work as
part of the ISS [International Space Station] program that is present at the
cosmodrome today won't stand idle in the future," Krasnikov said at a press
briefing on Tuesday.

"The Russian Federation has multitudes of its own programs, research programs,
which need to be implemented with the help of ISS capabilities. And of course
we'll continue sending our guys, our cosmonauts to it. Naturally, the Baikonur
Cosmodrome and the infrastructure that has been built there will be used for
this," he said.

"And the American side is also interested in continuing to use the
capabilities of our transportation system. We're very pleased with this.
Naturally, other states are interested too. [...] We've been working quite
seriously with this and of course hope and are even confident that the
cosmodrome will also be working quite actively for the benefit of the ISS and
the popularization of its program in the future. We're looking into the future
with optimism, and will continue the work that is presently being conducted,"
Krasnikov said.

NASA and SpaceX successfully launched the Demo-2 mission last Saturday,
sending the Crew Dragon spacecraft built by Elon Musk's SpaceX company into
space. The astronauts docked with the ISS and entered the station on May 31.

Space and Rocket Building

Roscosmos hopes Kazakhstan, Russia show interest in Baikonur jubilee -
representative

NUR-SULTAN. June 2 (Interfax) - Roscosmos hopes that the presidents of
Kazakhstan and Russia will take part in celebrations of the 65th anniversary
of the Baikonur Cosmodrome, Roscosmos representative in Kazakhstan Anatoly
Krasnikov said at a press briefing on Tuesday.

"Of course, there will be quite a lot of quests, including heads of the region
and, naturally, executives of the state corporation will be there. [...]
Hopefully, the leadership of our states will show interest in this significant
date, as well," Krasnikov said.

"Obviously, city residents will prepare certain festivities. There will
probably be events in Moscow, too," he said.

There were plans to celebrate the 65th anniversary of the Baikonur Cosmodrome
on June 2 but the celebrations were delayed until October 4 because of the
coronavirus.

Space and Rocket Building

Agreement on upgrading Gagarin's Start at Baikonur may be signed soon -
Rogozin

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Roscosmos hopes to complete talks soon on
upgrading the Gagarin's Start launch pad at the Baikonur Cosmodrome, head of
Roscosmos Dmitry Rogozin said.

"What allows us to think today that Baikonur will live on and the city will
develop? This is, above all, the continuation of the manned space flight
program, which we tie to the restoration of Gagarin's Start. Such talks are
currently in progress, and we hope they'll be completed soon and we'll start
actual, physical work on this first, legendary launch pad," Rogozin said in a
video address on the occasion of the 65th anniversary of Baikonur.

The future of the cosmodrome and the city is also linked to the Baiterek
project, from which Soyuz-5 rockets will be launched, he said.

"And when these launch pads become operational, and as far as I understand,
this will happen within the next few years, because the rocket itself is
already being built at a Samara enterprise, then there will be further, very
firm confidence that Baikonur will live on, not only in the programs for the
future development of the Russian space sector, but it'll also become a
crucial factor of connection between Russia and Kazakhstan," Rogozin said.

Kazakh Aerospace Committee Chairman Baubek Oralmagambetov said in February
that Kazakhstan hopes to sign such an agreement in the first half of 2020.

At the beginning of June last year, the Russian Direct Investment Fund and
investors from the United Arab Emirates signed an agreement with Roscosmos on
allocating $90 million for the restoration of Gagarin's Start.

It was reported in December 2019 that the agreement between Russia,
Kazakhstan, and the UAE on upgrading Gagarin's Start at the Baikonur
Cosmodrome was undergoing approval procedures in the states themselves.

Rogozin said earlier that Russia, Kazakhstan, and the UAE would sign a
trilateral agreement on the restoration of Gagarin's Start at Baikonur before
the end of 2019.

The Gagarin's Start launch pad was closed after the launch of the last Soyuz-
FG rocket on September 25, 2019.

Gagarin's Start, or Baikonur's Site No. 1, is the launch pad that was used for
the world's first human spaceflight, made by Soviet pilot and cosmonaut Yury
Gagarin on Vostok 1 on April 12, 1961.

Space and Rocket Building

Roscosmos hopes to coordinate space center agreement with Kazakhstan shortly

NUR-SULTAN. June 2 (Interfax) - Kazakhstan and Russia may soon coordinate an
agreement on the design and construction of ground elements of the Baiterek
space center, Roscosmos representative in Kazakhstan Anatoly Krasnikov said at
a press briefing on Tuesday.

"We have reached the stage of the agreement's coordination between the client,
i.e., Kazakhstan, and our enterprises, which will design this center
[Baiterek] and will perform the construction works, which will naturally
involve Kazakh enterprises," Krasnikov said.

"Hopefully, the agreement will be coordinated shortly," he said, adding that
the agreement "is quite large, sizable, and long-term."

"We're glad that Kazakhstan is ready to begin funding the project, which will
create the center's ground infrastructure. For our part, we are actively
designing the rocket, a new medium-lift rocket, which will be launched from
the center," Krasnikov said.

"We hope to fulfill our part of the deal in due time and expect the Kazakh
side to do its part of the job in due time, as well, so that we have a
serviceable space center to launch Russian rockets from," he said.

Space and Rocket Building

Russian specialists to fly to Kourou on June 6 to deal with Fregat booster
stage's problem

MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - Specialists from NPO Lavochkin are scheduled to
depart for the Guiana Space Center in Kourou, French Guiana, on June 6 to deal
with the oxidizer vapor alert at the facility storing Russia's Fregat booster
stage, an informed source told Interfax.

"A charter flight carrying NPO Lavochkin's technicians from Moscow to Cayenne
is scheduled for June 6," the source said.

The Roscosmos press service said earlier it was informed by the French side on
May 21, 2020, of sporadic oxidizer vapor alerts at the place where Russia's
Fregat booster stage is stored in Kourou.

Space and Rocket Building

Russian Emergency Situations Ministry asks for foreign satellite imagery of
Norilsk oil spill

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - Roscosmos is monitoring the situation in the wake
of the spill of diesel fuel in Norilsk and is planning to conduct an orbital
survey of the bridge collapse in the Murmansk region, the corporation said.

"In the interests of the International Charter 'Space and Major Disasters,'
monitoring of the following emergency situations has been conducted: the
aftermath of a hurricane in the Republic of Bangladesh and India; the
aftermath of a flood in the Republic of El Salvador; the fuel spill in
Norilsk," it said.

"At the same time, today, on June 4, 2020, at the Russian Emergency Situations
Ministry's request, the International Charter has been invoked for monitoring
the fuel spill in Norilsk using foreign Earth remote sensing spacecraft
belonging to the Charter's signatories," it said.

Russian satellites should also be engaged to survey the aftermath of the
bridge collapse in Murmansk, a volcanic eruption in the Sakhalin region, and
the construction of medical centers for coronavirus patients, it said.

The International Charter 'Space and Major Disasters' is a noncommercial
agreement whose signatories are entitled to receive free satellite imagery in
the event of major disasters.

Apart from Roscosmos, the agreement signatories also include the European
Space Agency, the national space agencies of Canada, France, India, Japan,
China, Germany, and the United Kingdom, the United States National Oceanic and
Atmospheric Administration, and some other organizations.

A fuel tank at Power Plant No. 3 of the Norilsk-Taymyr Energy Company (NTEC),
which is part of Norilsk Nickel and provides electricity for the Norilsk
industrial district, lost pressure on May 29, leaking oil products and causing
a fire. The tank contained more than 21,000 tonnes of diesel fuel, which has
leaked into the Daldykan and Ambarnaya Rivers flowing into Lake Pyasino.
According to Rosprirodnadzor, the depth of the petroleum product layer at the
scene has reached 20 centimeters.

Space and Rocket Building

Energomash reports successful trials of RD-180 engine for U.S. rockets

MOSCOW. June 5 (Interfax) - NPO Energomash has reported successful trials of
the RD-180 engine built for U.S. Atlas rockets, the company press service said
in a statement.

"The research and testing center of NPO Energomash, an affiliate of the
Roscosmos state corporation, has conducted another successful firing trial of
the RD-180 engine. The testing program was fully accomplished, and the trials
were normal," the statement said.

At present, RD-180 engines are used exclusively in U.S. Atlas rockets. The
first rocket powered by RD-180 was launched 20 years ago. Since then, the
United States has purchased 116 engines and performed 89 launches, all of them
successful, which is unique for the global space industry. Eleven RD-180
engines were supplied to U.S. customers in 2018. NPO Energomash sent three
more RD-180 engines to the United States in June 2019.

Despite the imposition of sanctions on Russia, the United States continued to
buy RD-180 engines and certified them for manned launches of new Boeing
Starliner spaceships.

Shipbuilding and Navy

Russian Navy to get 35 ships before yearend - commander

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Russian Navy will put on combat duty 35 ships
of various types before the end of 2020, Russian Navy Commander Adm. Nikolai
Yevmenov said.

"The flag will soon be raised on the Knyaz Vladimir nuclear-powered submarine,
which has successfully completed state trials. The flag will also be raised on
the Admiral Kasatonov frigate of Project 22350. In all, 35 ships of various
types will join the Navy by the end of 2020," the Krasnaya Zvezda newspaper of
the Russian Defense Ministry quoted Yevmenov as saying.

The main naval parade, which will be take place in particular at Russia's
naval base in Syria's port of Tartus, will be one of the most important tasks
in the summer training period, he said.

A report on the order of the organization of the main naval parade, which will
take place in St. Petersburg, Kronshtadt, main bases of the Russian fleets and
the Tartus base, has been presented and approved by Defense Minister Sergei
Shoigu at a recent meeting of the Russian Defense Ministry's board, he said.

The Navy "will continue accomplishing the task of its naval presence in the
World Ocean, the exploration of the Arctic zone, and tests of new hardware and
arms, which are shipped to the fleets," Yevmenov said.

"The potential of nuclear-powered submarines of the Northern and Pacific
Fleets will be maintained at a proper level. The serial construction of
Project 636.3 diesel-electric submarines for the Pacific Fleet, Project 22160
patrol ships for the Black Sea Fleet, Project 22800 small missile ships for
the Baltic Fleet, and also Project 12700 mine defense vessels will continue,"
he said.

Shipbuilding and Navy

Russia's Northern Fleet to practice firing strategic missiles in fall -
commander

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Northern Fleet will practice firing
intercontinental ballistic missiles in fall 2020, Northern Fleet Commander
Vice-Admiral Alexander Moiseyev said.

"The main final event of the training year will be the check of preparedness
of the group of strategic submarines, which will fire intercontinental
ballistic missiles. Traditionally, the event takes place in fall," Moiseyev
said in an interview with the Defense Ministry's newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda,
which was published on Monday.

As for this year's tasks, Moiseyev said that the Northern Fleet would
participate in testing new weapons.

"Trials of new samples of marine missile and torpedo weapons are scheduled to
take place within the Northern Fleet's zone of responsibility and with the
participation of our forces," he said.

The biggest and most important task of the short-term future is the Navy Day
events due in July, Moiseyev said.

Shipbuilding and Navy

Russia's Northern Fleet to receive 6 ships, subs in 2020 - commander

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Russia's Northern Fleet will be enhanced with the
Knyaz Vladimir strategic submarine, the Kazan multirole submarine, and the
Admiral Kasatonov stealth frigate in 2020, Northern Fleet Commander Vice-
Admiral Alexander Moiseyev said.

"Just this year, the Northern Fleet is expected to receive six surface ships,
submarines, and boats," Moiseyev said in an interview published by the Defense
Ministry's newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda on Monday.

"Soon enough, the fleet will be joined by the Knyaz Vladimir strategic
submarine and the Admiral Kasatonov frigate, which have successfully passed
state trials in the White and Barents Seas," he said

"Factory trials of the Pyotr Morgunov landing ship are also nearing
completion, and it will join the fleet shortly. The expected delivery of the
Kazan nuclear submarine of Project Yasen-M will considerably expand the combat
capacity of the group of carriers of precision-guided weapons," Moiseyev said.

"The third frigate of Project 22350, the Admiral Golovko, was launched on May
22. It will also join the Northern Fleet in due time. Advanced ships of the
project have proven their value: the Admiral Gorshkov frigate performed its
first round-the-world voyage last year," he said.

"The fleet's ground and coastal forces will be supplied with more than 180
pieces of weapons and military hardware customized for harsh Arctic conditions
by the end of the year," Moiseyev said.

"The proportion of modern weapons in the fleet is growing year upon year. It
currently exceeds 60%," Moiseyev said. "Tests of new weapons, including
hypersonic weapons, are ongoing; these weapons will improve the quality of the
Northern Fleet's combat potential," he said.

"We are successfully operating new types of marine hardware received over
recent years, including the unique multirole logistics and supply ship Elbrus,
the oceanographic research vessel Yantar, the diesel electric icebreaker Ilya
Muromets, the brand-new, medium-range ice-class tanker Akademik Nashin, and
anti-sabotage warfare boats of Project 21980 Grachyonok," Moiseyev said.

Shipbuilding and Navy

Russian Northern Fleet to be reinforced with new subs, ships - Navy commander

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Russian Northern Fleet will procure new
strategic submarines and surface ships, Russian Navy Commander Nikolai
Yevmenov said.

"The Northern Fleet is now an actively developing fleet in the Navy. All
components of the Northern Fleet will continue to be equipped with the state-
of-the-art equipment and weapons. The prospects for the development of the
Northern Fleet have clear directions and specific tracks," Yevmenov said on
June 1, the Russian Northern Fleet Day.

"The Northern Fleet will continue to get Borei-A and Yasen-M nuclear-powered
submarines. It's a program track aimed at ruling out any threats from sea and
oceanic directions," Russian Navy spokesperson Igor Dygalo quoted Yevmenov as
saying.

"The construction of the series of frigates of Project 22350 frigates and
later their modifications will continue. The Admiral Kasatonov frigate will
join the surface component of the Northern Fleet this year," Yevmenov said.

"In the future, the Northern Fleet will also procure the state-of-the-art mine
defense vessels of Project 12700, which have already proven effective," he
said.

Shipbuilding and Navy

Russia's Northern Fleet commander announces hypersonic weapons tests

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Russia's Northern Fleet is expecting to receive
hypersonic weapons and is preparing for their tests, Northern Fleet Commander
Alexander Moiseyev said.

"We will continue to test new weapons, including hypersonic ones, which would
qualitatively bolster the Northern Fleet's combat capability," Moiseyev said
in an interview published in the Defense Ministry's official newspaper
Krasnaya Zvezda.

In March, Moiseyev said that the Northern Fleet's submarines were planning to
start testing hypersonic weapons.

"Northern Fleet submariners are regularly involved in testing new weaponry.
Our submarines should start testing hypersonic weapons in the near future.
We've already received such an assignment," Moiseyev said at the time.

As reported earlier, Russia has designed and developed the Tsirkon sea-
launched hypersonic missile, which is to undergo tests.

Shipbuilding and Navy

Russia's Baltic Fleet to get Kalibr-carrying ship in 2020

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Odintsovo small missile ship will join the
Russian Navy this year, Russia's Baltic Fleet said.

"Another small missile ship, the Odintsovo, of Project 22800 Karakurt, which
is now undergoing builder's trials, will join the fleet at the end of this
year," the fleet said in a statement obtained by Interfax.

"The Baltic Fleet will continue active missions in the near future," the
report said.

"A lot of attention will be given to the work of all-arms groups of ships in
the near-range sea zone. Several tactical, bilateral exercises and drills are
scheduled to take place in the Baltic Sea. The fleet's ships will continue
accomplishing tasks in the Northern Atlantic and in the Mediterranean as part
of 10 long-range missions," the statement said.

The Odintsovo is the ship of Project 22800 equipped with the Pantsir-M air
defense system, which is a naval version of the Pantsir-S air defense missile
and gun system.

Small missile ships of Project 22800 are designed for accomplishing tasks both
solely and as part of warships units. They are equipped with high-precision
weapons, state-of-the-art command systems, electronic warfare, radio
communication and navigation systems, countersabotage weapons, and MANPADs.
The Baltic Fleet now has two Project 22800 ships, the Mytishchy and the
Sovetsk.

Shipbuilding and Navy

Stealth frigate Admiral Kasatonov fires anti-torpedo system in Baltic Sea as
part of trials

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - The frigate Admiral Kasatonov, which is undergoing
the final stage of state trials, held an anti-torpedo live-fire drill in the
waters of the Baltic Sea, the Baltic Fleet's press service told Interfax.

"In the maritime training areas of the Baltic Fleet, the crew of the ship,
jointly with industry representatives, practiced ship defense using anti-
torpedoes from the Paket small-sized antisubmarine system," the press service
said.

The frigate was "attacked" by a practice torpedo of the small antisubmarine
ship Aleksin. The attack was successfully repelled.

On May 21 the fleet's press service stated that the frigate was out in the sea
for the final stage of trials. The frigate crossed into the Baltic Sea in
April. After completing all tests, it will be handed over to the Russian Navy.
The handover is scheduled for late May - early June this year, its
manufacturer, Severnaya Verf, said.

The Admiral Kasatonov is the second new frigate built under Project 22350. The
lead ship, Admiral Gorshkov, was handed over to the Navy in July 2018.

Project 22350 ships are made using stealth technology, are designed to operate
in remote oceanic zones against enemy surface ships and submarines, and are
capable of repelling air raids either independently or as part of a naval
unit.

These frigates are armed with a 130mm A-192 artillery gun, a Redut anti-
aircraft missile system, and launchers for 16 Oniks or Kalibr-NK anti-ship
missiles. They also carry the Paket-NK system as an anti-submarine weapon and
the Kamov Ka-27 anti-submarine helicopter.

Shipbuilding and Navy

New Arctic research vessel undergo state trials in northern Russia

MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - The Northern Fleet has begun state trials of the
Nikolai Skosyrev state-of-the-art hydrographic ship designed for Arctic
operations, the fleet's press service said.

"The Northern Fleet began the state trials of the Nikolai Skosyrev small
hydrographic vessel built by the Rybinsk-based Vympel shipyard today. It moved
through the White Sea Canal system to the Kola Bay last November. Tomorrow it
will make its first outing to the Barents sea," the press service said in a
statement on Tuesday.

The ship will test its maneuverability and seakeeping ability, loading devices
and special hydrographic equipment.

The Project 19910 ship is designed for hydrographic research and providing
guidance for sea navigation in the Arctic. Its hull has been reinforced to an
ice-class, enabling it to sail through cut ice up to 80 centimeters thick
without an icebreaker.

Vympel shipyard is now building the project's second ship, Yakov Lapushkin.

Ordnance

Russian military receives batch of modernized Msta-S howitzers - Rostec

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Uralvagonzavod, Russia's leading manufacturer of
heavy weapon systems and military vehicles, has modernized the Msta-S self-
propelled artillery gun, the first batch of which has been delivered to the
military, the Rostec state corporation said.

"In the course of their overhaul and modernization, the Msta-S self-propelled
howitzers were outfitted with automated targeting and fire control systems,"
Rostec said on Tuesday.

Uraltransmash has carried out the overhaul and modernization of the 2S19
Msta-S howitzers delivered earlier to the Armed Forces, it said.

"The Msta-S self-propelled artillery vehicle has been outfitted with a new
automated targeting and fire control system. Its use cuts the time for the
gun's deployment at a firing position by up to a half, which significantly
increases the combat vehicle's survivability," Rostec quoted Dmitry Semizorov,
general director of Uraltransmash, as saying.

The self-propelled 2S19M1 howitzer is designed to destroy and suppress
artillery mortar batteries, tanks, antitank, firepower and electronic warfare
systems, armor, command centers, air defense and missile defense systems, as
well as for the destruction of field defense fortifications, and obstruction
of maneuvers of personnel and tank reserves.

Ordnance

Factory for manufacture of Kalashnikov assault rifles to open in Armenia in
July - media

YEREVAN. June 4 (Interfax) - A factory for manufacturing Kalashnikov assault
rifles will start working in Armenia in July, the Armenian state information
agency Armenpress said, citing the enterprise's CEO Igor Gordiyenko.

"AK-103 [assault rifles] will be assembled at the factory during the first
stage. The assembly will take place from scratch, parts will be supplied from
Russia during the initial stage [...] The second stage envisages the
production of the simple parts necessary for on-site assembly, again using
Russian technologies," Gordiyenko said.

The enterprise was created under a cooperation agreement between the company
Neitron GAM and the Russian concern Kalashnikov, which was signed on May 15,
2020, for a period of ten years.

Ordnance

Kalashnikov factory in Armenia will produce up to 50,000 AK-103 rifles
annually - FSMTC

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - An Armenian factory will begin assembling
Kalashnikov AK-103 assault rifles in July under a license issued for 10 years,
spokesperson for Russia's Federal Service for Military-Technical Cooperation
(FSMTC) Maria Vorobyova told Interfax on Thursday.

"Production capacity will be up to 50,000 items annually. The validity period
of the license is 10 years," Vorobyova said.

Russia and Armenia earlier signed a contract on the delivery of components as
part of organizing the step-by-step assembly of AK-103 assault rifles in
Armenia in implementation of the relevant FSMTC resolution dated May 15, 2020.

It is planned that the Armenian factory will start producing AK-103 rifles in
the first ten days of July 2020.

Chemical Disarmament and Military Ecology

Russia to test Covid-19 vaccine on 50 volunteers from military personnel -
Russian Defense Ministry

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Russia is launching clinical trials of a Covid-19
vaccine on volunteers among Russian Armed Forces personnel, the Russian
Defense Ministry said on Tuesday.

"The Defense Ministry of Russia has finished selecting volunteers for clinical
trials of a one-of-a-kind domestically developed vaccine for the novel
coronavirus infection Covid-19. Fifty military personnel, among them five
women, who volunteered to take part in trials of the new vaccine, have been
selected for tests of the vaccine's safety and effectiveness," the ministry
said in a press release shared with Interfax.

The Covid-19 vaccine in question was developed with the help of the Russian
military, namely the Russian Defense Ministry's 48th Central Scientific
Research Institute, which will host the clinical trials.

"The first group of volunteer servicemen is expected to arrive at a
specialized medical center at the 48th Central Scientific Research Institute
of the Russian Defense Ministry on June 3 to undergo a preliminary in-depth
health checkup and prepare for the experiment," the ministry said.

All candidates already underwent a preliminary health checkup and testing and
have not been diagnosed with any diseases for a month, it said.

The participants in the clinical trials were selected from different Armed
Forces units from all over the country, it said.

The clinical trials of the vaccine will be carried out on the premises of the
48th Central Scientific Research Institute, which previously hosted successful
trials of vaccines for Ebola, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, and a
universal flu vaccine, the military said.

Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu told President Vladimir Putin on May 26
that clinical trials of the coronavirus vaccine will be completed before the
end of July.

The vaccine is being developed by the 48th Central Scientific Research
Institute of the Radiation, Chemical, and Biological Protection Troops of the
Defense Ministry together with the Nikolai Gamaleya National Epidemiology and
Microbiology Research Center of the Health Ministry. The 48th Central
Scientific Research Institute specializes in developing medical protection
against particularly dangerous diseases for the Armed Forces and the civilian
population.

Chemical Disarmament and Military Ecology

Coronavirus outbreaks averted in Russian military units - Shoigu

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Outbreaks of coronavirus have been averted in
Russian military units, and most of the 6,500 coronavirus patients in the
military have now recovered, Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu said at a
teleconference on Tuesday.

"The timely implementation of a package of anti-epidemic measures and systemic
round-the-clock control over these measures by the operative headquarters
enabled us to avert Covid-19 outbreaks in military units," Shoigu said.

"A total of 6,500 persons associated with the Armed Forces have contracted the
infection since early March, and over 4,300 of them have already been
discharged from hospitals," he said.

The number of recoveries daily has been exceeding the number of current
patients since May 9, Shoigu said.

Additionally, all troops are regularly tested for coronavirus, Shoigu said.

Russia deploys specialists to Turkey to service S-400 air defense missile
systems - FSMTC head

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Russian technicians are helping Turkish colleagues
service S-400 air defense missile systems which were supplied to Turkey under
the first bilateral contract for such systems, head of the Federal Service for
Military-Technical Cooperation (FSMTC) Dmitry Shugayev said.

"A warranty team of Russian specialists has been posted to Turkey to assist
our Turkish colleagues with the operation of this equipment," Shugayev said on
the Ekoturk television channel.

Chemical Disarmament and Military Ecology

Russian Armed Forces record over 4,000 recoveries from Covid-19 among
personnel

MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - The Russian Armed Forces have registered more than
4,000 recoveries from coronavirus within the system, the Defense Ministry said
on Tuesday.

"The total number of recoveries in the Russian Armed Forces has increased to
3,881," the ministry stated on its website.

Among civilian personnel, the figure is 340, it said.

The current number of infections is 1,444 among servicemen in military
commands, units and formations, 436 cadets and students of military academies,
and 360 civilian specialists, the ministry said.

Chemical Disarmament and Military Ecology

Covid-19 vaccine developed jointly with Russian military ready for clinical
trials

MOSCOW. June 5 (Interfax) - Preparations have been completed for the start of
clinical trials of a Covid-19 vaccine, which has been developed by the Russian
military together with the Nikolai Gamaleya National Epidemiology and
Microbiology Research Center, employee of a branch of the Burdenko Main
Military Hospital Natalya Pozdnyakova said.

Fifty volunteers have been selected among Russian Armed Forces personnel for
participation in the clinical trials, while the vaccine itself have already
undergone tests for toxicity, safety, immunogenicity, and protective
efficiency on large and small animals (monkeys and hamsters) at the 48th
Central Scientific Research Institute of the Russian Defense Ministry, she
said.

"In such a way, the Defense Ministry together with the Nikolai Gamaleya
National Epidemiology and Microbiology Research Center has completed
preparations for the start of clinical trials of this unique domestic vaccine
for the Covid-19 coronavirus infection," the Defense Ministry's Krasnaya
Zvezda newspaper quoted Pozdnyakova as saying.

During the selection of candidates, each volunteer was required to undergo a
full range of medical examinations, she said.

A separate, isolated hospital building was allocated for the selected
volunteers, who include 45 men and five women. Prior to that, the building was
fully disinfected and all of its premises were sanitized. The volunteers were
transported to the site of the experiment by previously disinfected vehicles.

"All of them are serving under contract. They are warrant officers and
officers aged between 25 and 50 years old, since legislation of the Russian
Federation prohibits conducting trials on conscripts," Pozdnyakova said.

These 50 volunteers include ten healthcare workers, including three doctors.

Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu told President Vladimir Putin during a
videoconference on May 26 that the 48th Central Scientific Research Institute
of the Radiation, Chemical, and Biological Protection Troops of the Defense
Ministry together with the Nikolai Gamaleya National Epidemiology and
Microbiology Research Center are developing a recombinant vaccine for the
novel coronavirus. Clinical trials of the vaccine are expected to be completed
before the end of July.

Hard to tell due to coronavirus when contract for 2nd regimental set of S-400
systems might be concluded with Turkey \- FSMTC head

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Negotiations on the delivery of the second
regimental set of S-400 air defense missile systems to Turkey have reached an
advanced stage, head of the Federal Service for Military-Technical Cooperation
(FSMTC) Dmitry Shugayev said.

"Dialogue on the delivery of the second regimental set of S-400 systems has
reached quite an advanced stage, and we are awaiting Turkey's final decision,"
Shugayev said on the Ekoturk television channel.

Given the restrictions caused by the coronavirus pandemic, "it is a thankless
task to predict when the contract might be concluded," he said.

systems - FSMTC head

service S-400 air defense missile systems which were supplied to Turkey under
the first bilateral contract for such systems, head of the Federal Service for
Military-Technical Cooperation (FSMTC) Dmitry Shugayev said.

"A warranty team of Russian specialists has been posted to Turkey to assist
our Turkish colleagues with the operation of this equipment," Shugayev said on

Arms Trade

Turkey's orders for Russian military hardware estimated at approx. $1 bln \-
FSMTC head

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Turkey's book of orders for Russian military
hardware stands at approximately $1 billion, Director of Russia's Federal
Service for Military-Technical Cooperation (FSMTC) Dmitry Shugayev said.

"The book of orders with Turkey for Russian hardware is estimated at around $1
billion," Shugayev told the Ekoturk television channel.

The latest products of the aircraft industry and more were demonstrated to
Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan at the Russian MAKS air show, he said.

"It's not a secret that our partners were greatly impressed by our aircraft.
Besides, dialogue on a number of other avenues of military-technical
cooperation, including future ones, has taken shape," Shugayev said.

Relations between Moscow and Ankara in the field of military-technical
cooperation reached a new level after the S-400 delivery contract was signed,
he said.

"Turkey became one of the top five largest buyers of Russian hardware for the
first time," Shugayev said.

Arms Trade

Russia prepared to consider Turkey's involvement in manufacturing S-400
systems - FSMTC head

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Russia stands ready to discuss the involvement of
Turkish companies in the manufacture of S-400 Triumph air defense systems,
Director of the Russian Federal Service for Military-Technical Cooperation
(FSMTC) Dmitry Shugayev said.

"We are prepared to explore opportunities for technological cooperation. That
is, the involvement of Turkish companies in the manufacturing process,"
Shugayev said in an interview shown on the Ekoturk television channel.

Such negotiations are currently ongoing, but "this is a painstaking process
requiring a certain amount of time," he said.

"Obviously, this format of cooperation envisions a new stage in our
interaction: a more sophisticated and trusting one, in which it will be
important to strike a balance in protecting our interests," Shugayev said.

Arms Trade

Russia ready to supply Su-35 jets to Turkey, joint production of aircraft, air
defense systems being discussed - FSMTC head

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Russian and Turkish specialists are discussing
joint projects in the fields of aviation and air defense, Director of the
Russian Federal Service for Military-Technical Cooperation (FSMTC) Dmitry
Shugayev said.

"At the moment, our specialists are discussing possible options for
cooperation in the joint production of aircraft and air defense systems. I
have no doubt that the potential for our interaction is not limited to this,"
Shugayev said on the Ekoturk television channel on Tuesday.

As for the possible delivery of Sukhoi Su-35 fighters to Turkey, Shugayev
said, "If Turkey chooses to buy such aircraft, we'll be ready to hold the
relevant consultations with our colleagues."

Speaking of the Su-57 fifth-generation aircraft, Shugayev said they are
currently being supplied only to the Russian Defense Ministry. "We cannot
speak of the possibility of their export to any country, including Turkey," he
said.

Arms Trade

Russia deploys specialists to Turkey to service S-400 air defense missile
systems - FSMTC head

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Russian technicians are helping Turkish colleagues
service S-400 air defense missile systems which were supplied to Turkey under
the first bilateral contract for such systems, head of the Federal Service for
Military-Technical Cooperation (FSMTC) Dmitry Shugayev said.

"A warranty team of Russian specialists has been posted to Turkey to assist
our Turkish colleagues with the operation of this equipment," Shugayev said on
the Ekoturk television channel.

Russia has fully met its obligations to deliver S-400 systems to Turkey under
the earlier contract, and Turkish servicemen have been trained in Russia to
operate the system, he said.

Shugayev described the contract for the delivery of S-400 systems to Turkey as
significant, considering the huge pressure coming from NATO, first and
foremost from the United States.

"The contract was successfully fulfilled last year, thanks to the combined
efforts of both countries," Shugayev said.

Arms Trade

Russia working on export version of Armata tank - source

MOSCOW. June 5 (Interfax) - Russia has begun working on the export version of
its Armata tank, an informed source told Interfax.

"Work to prepare the product for export is in progress: specialists are
deciding which [elements] could be included in the export version and which
elements will be installed only on tanks intended for the [Russian] military,"
the source said.

However, Armata exports should not be expected to start until all supply
obligations to the Russian Defense Ministry are fulfilled, the source said.

"T-90 tanks in different modifications are being exported presently. This is
where focus will be placed for now," he said.

Meanwhile, another source told Interfax that the Armata has already received
its export certificate.

Interfax does not have official confirmation of the report.

Russia has received preliminary applications for Armata tanks from foreign
customers, Russian Industry and Trade Minister Denis Manturov said in April.

Manturov also said that the T-14 Armata had been tested in Syria. The Russian
Defense Ministry, for its part, did not report any Armata trials in Syria.

According to earlier reports, Uralvagonzavod developed the Armata heavy
tracked vehicle platform. The T-14 tank, the T-15 infantry fighting vehicle,
and the T-16 armored repair and evacuation vehicle are based on the platform.
Armata-based vehicles are now undergoing trials.

The T-14 is the world's only tank of the third post-war generation. Military
experts see it as a cutting-edge, one-of-a-kind tank. The Armata tank is a
completely new and fully Russian development. Equipped with an unmanned
turret, it is the first tank where the crew is placed in an armored capsule
separated from the ammunition load.

Exhibitions

Some elements of 1945 Victory Parade to be reconstructed during June 24, 2020
parade - Russian Ground Forces commander

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - The Victory Parade on Red Square in Moscow on June
24, 2020 will begin at 10:00 a.m. Moscow Time, will last for up to an hour and
a half, and will include some elements of the historic parade of June 24,
1945, Russian Ground Forces Commander Col. Gen. Oleg Salyukov said at a
teleconference on Tuesday.

"The start of the Victory Parade is set for 10:00 a.m. on June 24," Salyukov
said.

"The overall duration of the parade will be up to an hour and a half,"
Salyukov said.

The parade scenario and the sequence in which the military columns are to pass
will remain the same, he said.

The number of ceremonial details of the Russian Armed Forces for the June 24
parade has been updated, and the organizers are finalizing the determination
of foreign military units to take part in the parade, he said.

"During the ceremonial events, some elements of the historic parade of June
24, 1945 are to be used. For example, the Jubilee Slow March will be played at
the beginning of the parade, and an identical firework show is planned for the
evening," he said.

title: Interfax Russia & CIS Defense Industry Weekly
html:
Corridors of Power

Ankara makes its own decisions on using S-400 - Russian ambassador

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - Turkey is free to choose whether or not to put the S-400 air defense missile systems supplied from Russia on combat duty, Russian Ambassador in Ankara Alexei Yerkhov said.

"The decision whether or not to put a particular weapon system on combat duty is the sovereign decision of the weapon's owner," the embassy quoted Yerkhov as saying in a statement published on its website.

"Turkey made a sovereign decision to buy this kind of weapon from the Russian Federation," he said.

"Good, we respect their decision. We sold Turkey what it wanted to buy from us. Now these systems are owned by Turkey. And it will make the relevant decision," Yerkhov said.

Corridors of Power

Russian, S. Korean PMs discuss prospects for economic projects involving N. Korea

MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin and his South Korean counterpart Chung Sye-kyun have discussed in a telephone call the prospects for implementing trilateral projects involving Russia, South Korea, and North Korea, the Russian government's press service said.

During the phone conversation, the prime ministers expressed "their mutual interest in intensifying trade, economic, scientific, and technological cooperation, as well as cooperation in the fields of energy and transport infrastructure," the press service said.

They also discussed the schedule of upcoming contacts between the two countries' governments, it said.

Corridors of Power

Russia ships new batch of MiG-29 fighter jets to Syria - Russian embassy

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - Russia has shipped a new batch of MiG-29 fighter aircraft to Syria, the Russian embassy to Syria said.

"Syrian Arab Army received the second batch of advanced MiG-29 fighter jets from Russia," the embassy said on Twitter.

The planes have been shipped as part of military and technical cooperation between the two countries, and Syrian pilots have already started flying the planes, it said.

The Syrian state news agency SANA reported citing a source on May 30 that the Syrian army received a unit of Russian MiG-29s. The handover ceremony took place at the Russian airbase Hmeimim in Syria, it said.

Corridors of Power

Ankara makes its own decisions on using S-400 - Russian ambassador

MOSCOW. June 4 (Interfax) - Turkey is free to choose whether or not to put the S-400 air defense missile systems supplied from Russia on combat duty, Russian Ambassador in Ankara Alexei Yerkhov said.

"The decision whether or not to put a particular weapon system on combat duty is the sovereign decision of the weapon's owner," the embassy quoted Yerkhov as saying in a statement published on its website.

"Turkey made a sovereign decision to buy this kind of weapon from the Russian Federation," he said.

"Good, we respect their decision. We sold Turkey what it wanted to buy from us. Now these systems are owned by Turkey. And it will make the relevant decision," Yerkhov said.

The diplomat compared Turkey's decision to activate the S-400 systems with the decision to start using a purchased vehicle.

"Say I'm a car dealer. You come to me and say you want to buy a car. Alright. We conclude an agreement, you pay the money, and I give you the car and the keys. The car is yours. You can drive it to the beach or use it to transport potatoes. If you want, you can install a machinegun on the roof and fight a war. You can also park your car in the garage. That's your decision," Yerkhov said.

Corridors of Power

Two FSMTC, Trade Ministry employees suspected of corruption - source

"Chief executive officer of NAO LLC Vasily Klepalov, deputy head of a division at FSMTC Sergei Garmash and a head of department at the Ministry of Industry and Trade Rizvan Gayrbekov were detained yesterday in a criminal case as people suspected of giving and accepting a bribe (Articles 290 and 291 of the Russian Criminal Code)," the source said.

Roscosmos on Crew Dragon's launch: It is very important to have two options of traveling to ISS

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Russian state space corporation Roscosmos has welcomed Saturday's successful launch of the manned aircraft Crew Dragon in the U.S. and noted the importance of a co-existence of two transport systems that can deliver crews to the International Space Station.

"It is very important to have at least two opportunities to get to the station. Since you never know... Things have happened in space, and there should be at least two transport systems capable of ensuring the presence of crews from different countries on board the ISS," Roscosmos spokesman Vladimir Ustimenko wrote on Twitter.

Commenting on the successful launch of Crew Dragon, Ustimenko said, "What has happened should have happened a long time ago. Now not only the Russians but also the Americans will fly to the ISS. That's great!"

As reported earlier, a SpaceX capsule carrying two NASA astronauts docked at the ISS at 5:16 p.m. Moscow time on Sunday.

Crew Dragon, on board of which two NASA astronauts, Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley, departed from Cape Canaveral in Florida on Saturday afternoon to reach the ISS in about 19 hours, is the first manned aircraft launched form the U.S. since 2011, when the final space shuttle mission was completed.

The two U.S. astronauts lifted off in SpaceX's Crew Dragon spacecraft on a Falcon 9 rocket from Launch Complex 39A in Florida at 3:22 p.m. EDT on May 30. Initially, the launch was due earlier on May 27 but ended up being delayed 15 minutes to blast-off due to bad weather.

The launch was performed under the contract between NASA and SpaceX on creating an aircraft and a launch vehicle for commercial manned missions to the ISS.

This Crew Dragon mission is the spaceship's last big trial before a NASA certification for regular commercial manned missions to the ISS. In March 2019, a similar pilotless spacecraft completed the first successful experimental spaceflight to the station.

Since 2011, U.S. astronauts had been using Russia's Soyuz spacecraft to reach the ISS. NASA pays Russia for seats on board a Soyuz spacecraft. In particular, This May, NASA agreed to pay Roscosmos $90.2 million for one seat on board the Soyuz, which is due to depart for the ISS on October.

Roscosmos head Dmitry Rogozin said on May 25 that Russia was following with interest preparations for the launch of the manned spacecraft Crew Dragon to the ISS. The return of Americans to this work will help increase the number of Russian cosmonauts on board the station, he said.

"It is with great interest that we're watching the preparations for this launch. We have several motives for this. Indeed, for the past nine years, since summer 2011, only Russia, only Roscosmos, has facilitated the delivery of all international crews to the ISS: Americans, Europeans, the Japanese, and Canadians," Rogozin said on the Komsomolskaya Pravda radio station.

"Yes, we have, of course, made some money on that, but in fact, the responsibility associated with supporting this transport system, the continual delivery to the ISS, has been colossal; it's not worth the money: the cost is nerves, the health of the people in charge of manned space," Rogozin said.

"We would be very happy if the Americans came up with an alternative manned transport system. It's a natural process, such a great power as the U.S., I imagine what they went through all these nine years, not being able to deliver astronauts to the ISS on their spacecraft [...] Let's wish them professional success," he said.

Russia is also interested in the technical side of the project, Rogozin said.

Unburdening Russian spacecraft will help increase the number of cosmonauts on the station, he said. "We've reduced our crews to two cosmonauts, who are in orbit continually. Sometimes there was only one, the captain, in orbit. This is wrong. This hinders the entire scientific program which we associate with the ISS," Rogozin said.

Russia's Northern Fleet commander announces hypersonic weapons tests

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - Russia's Northern Fleet is expecting to receive hypersonic weapons and is preparing for their tests, Northern Fleet Commander Alexander Moiseyev said.

"We will continue to test new weapons, including hypersonic ones, which would qualitatively bolster the Northern Fleet's combat capability," Moiseyev said in an interview published in the Defense Ministry's official newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda.

In March, Moiseyev said that the Northern Fleet's submarines were planning to start testing hypersonic weapons.

"Northern Fleet submariners are regularly involved in testing new weaponry. Our submarines should start testing hypersonic weapons in the near future. We've already received such an assignment," Moiseyev said at the time.

As reported earlier, Russia has designed and developed the Tsirkon sea-launched hypersonic missile, which is to undergo tests.

Shipbuilding and Navy

Russia's Baltic Fleet to get Kalibr-carrying ship in 2020

MOSCOW. June 1 (Interfax) - The Odintsovo small missile ship will join the Russian Navy this year, Russia's Baltic Fleet said.

"Another small missile ship, the Odintsovo, of Project 22800 Karakurt, which is now undergoing builder's trials, will join the fleet at the end of this year," the fleet said in a statement obtained by Interfax.

"The Baltic Fleet will continue active missions in the near future," the report said.

"A lot of attention will be given to the work of all-arms groups of ships in the near-range sea zone. Several tactical, bilateral exercises and drills are scheduled to take place in the Baltic Sea. The fleet's ships will continue accomplishing tasks in the Northern Atlantic and in the Mediterranean as part of 10 long-range missions," the statement said.

The Odintsovo is the ship of Project 22800 equipped with the Pantsir-M air defense system, which is a naval version of the Pantsir-S air defense missile and gun system.

Small missile ships of Project 22800 are designed for accomplishing tasks both solely and as part of warships units. They are equipped with high-precision weapons, state-of-the-art command systems, electronic warfare, radio communication and navigation systems, countersabotage weapons, and MANPADs. The Baltic Fleet now has two Project 22800 ships, the Mytishchy and the Sovetsk.

Shipbuilding and Navy

Stealth frigate Admiral Kasatonov fires anti-torpedo system in Baltic Sea as part of trials

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - The frigate Admiral Kasatonov, which is undergoing the final stage of state trials, held an anti-torpedo live-fire drill in the waters of the Baltic Sea, the Baltic Fleet's press service told Interfax.

"In the maritime training areas of the Baltic Fleet, the crew of the ship, jointly with industry representatives, practiced ship defense using anti-torpedoes from the Paket small-sized antisubmarine system," the press service said.

The frigate was "attacked" by a practice torpedo of the small antisubmarine ship Aleksin. The attack was successfully repelled.

On May 21 the fleet's press service stated that the frigate was out in the sea for the final stage of trials. The frigate crossed into the Baltic Sea in April. After completing all tests, it will be handed over to the Russian Navy. The handover is scheduled for late May - early June this year, its manufacturer, Severnaya Verf, said.

The Admiral Kasatonov is the second new frigate built under Project 22350. The lead ship, Admiral Gorshkov, was handed over to the Navy in July 2018.

Project 22350 ships are made using stealth technology, are designed to operate in remote oceanic zones against enemy surface ships and submarines, and are capable of repelling air raids either independently or as part of a naval unit.

These frigates are armed with a 130mm A-192 artillery gun, a Redut anti-aircraft missile system, and launchers for 16 Oniks or Kalibr-NK anti-ship missiles. They also carry the Paket-NK system as an anti-submarine weapon and the Kamov Ka-27 anti-submarine helicopter.

Shipbuilding and Navy

New Arctic research vessel undergo state trials in northern Russia

MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - The Northern Fleet has begun state trials of the Nikolai Skosyrev state-of-the-art hydrographic ship designed for Arctic operations, the fleet's press service said.

"The Northern Fleet began the state trials of the Nikolai Skosyrev small hydrographic vessel built by the Rybinsk-based Vympel shipyard today. It moved through the White Sea Canal system to the Kola Bay last November. Tomorrow it will make its first outing to the Barents sea," the press service said in a statement on Tuesday.

The ship will test its maneuverability and seakeeping ability, loading devices and special hydrographic equipment.

The Project 19910 ship is designed for hydrographic research and providing guidance for sea navigation in the Arctic. Its hull has been reinforced to an ice-class, enabling it to sail through cut ice up to 80 centimeters thick without an icebreaker.

Vympel shipyard is now building the project's second ship, Yakov Lapushkin.

Ordnance

Russian military receives batch of modernized Msta-S howitzers - Rostec

MOSCOW. June 2 (Interfax) - Uralvagonzavod, Russia's leading manufacturer of heavy weapon systems and military vehicles, has modernized the Msta-S self-propelled artillery gun, the first batch of which has been delivered to the military, the Rostec state corporation said.

"In the course of their overhaul and modernization, the Msta-S self-propelled howitzers were outfitted with automated targeting and fire control systems," Rostec said on Tuesday.

Uraltransmash has carried out the overhaul and modernization of the 2S19 Msta-S howitzers delivered earlier to the Armed Forces, it said.

"The Msta-S self-propelled artillery vehicle has been outfitted with a new automated targeting and fire control system. Its use cuts the time for the gun's deployment at a firing position by up to a half, which significantly increases the combat vehicle's survivability," Rostec quoted Dmitry Semizorov, general director of Uraltransmash, as saying.

The self-propelled 2S19M1 howitzer is designed to destroy and suppress artillery mortar batteries, tanks, antitank, firepower and electronic warfare systems, armor, command centers, air defense and missile defense systems, as well as for the destruction of field defense fortifications, and obstruction of maneuvers of personnel and tank reserves.

Factory for manufacture of Kalashnikov assault rifles to open in Armenia in July - media

YEREVAN. June 4 (Interfax) - A factory for manufacturing Kalashnikov assault rifles will start working in Armenia in July, the Armenian state information agency Armenpress said, citing the enterprise's CEO Igor Gordiyenko.

"AK-103 [assault rifles] will be assembled at the factory during the first stage. The assembly will take place from scratch, parts will be supplied from Russia during the initial stage [...] The second stage envisages the production of the simple parts necessary for on-site assembly, again using Russian technologies," Gordiyenko said.

The enterprise was created under a cooperation agreement between the company Neitron GAM and the Russian concern Kalashnikov, which was signed on May 15, 2020, for a period of ten years.
